After the final centrifugation, the sedimented fraction was homogenized in a solution containing 0.3 M sucrose, 0.15 M potassium gluconate, proteolytic enzyme inhibitors (0.1 mM phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride, 10 μg/ml aprotinin, 0.8 μg/ml antipain, 2 μg/ml trypsin inhibitor) and 20 mM MES, pH 6.8 (PI buffer), to a final protein concentration of 20-30 mg/ml. The preparation was quickly frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −70°C.Site-directed Labeling of the Junctional Foot Protein with the Fluorescent Conformational ProbeSpecific fluorescent labeling of the JFP moiety of the triad was performed using the cleavable hetero-bifunctional cross-linking reagent, sulfosuccinimidyl 3-((2-(7-azido-4-methylcoumarin-3-acetamido)ethyl)dithio)propionate (SAED; (16Kang J.J. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar) with the aid of neomycin as a site-specific carrier as follows. First, neomycin-SAED conjugates were formed by incubating 0.4 mM neomycin with 0.2 mM SAED in 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.5) for 15 min at 22° in the dark. The reaction was quenched by a 10-fold dilution with 10 mM lysine. Fifty μl of neomycin-SAED conjugate (final neomycin concentration was 2 μM) were mixed in the dark with 1 mg of triad protein, brought to 1 ml with PI buffer, and centrifuged for 15 min at 100,000 × g. The sedimented fraction was resuspended in 1 ml of PI buffer and photolyzed with UV light in a Pyrex tube at 4°C for 10 min. β-Mercaptoethanol was added (100 mM final) to cleave the disulfide bond of SAED. After incubation on ice for 1 h, the mixture was again centrifuged for 15 min at 100,000 × g, and the sedimented triads were resuspended in 50 μl of PI buffer to a final protein concentration of 20 mg/ml. The MCA incorporation was also done using polylysine as a site-directing carrier as described previously(16Kang J.J. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). In agreement with our previous report, these procedures (both neomycin- and polylysine-mediated incorporation) resulted in the specific incorporation of the MCA into the JFP moiety of the triad as determined by fluorometry of electrophoretically separated protein bands (data not shown).Induction and Monitoring of Depolarization-induced Ca2+ ReleaseTo depolarize the T-tubule moiety of the triad, we used the Na+-replacement protocol that had been originally used to produce T-tubule-mediated tension development in the skinned fiber system (21Lamb G.D. Stephenson D.G. J. Physiol. 1990; 423: 495-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 22Lamb G.D. Stephenson D.G. J. Physiol. 1990; 423: 519-542Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) and more recently adapted to the isolated triad system(17Ikemoto N. Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Morii M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 10961-10968Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). The fluorescently labeled triads (1.6 mg/ml) were incubated in the priming solution (Solution A) containing 150 mM potassium gluconate, 15 mM NaCl, 5 mM Mg•ATP, an ATP-regenerating system (2.5 mM phosphoenolpyruvate, 10 units/ml pyruvate kinase), 100-150 μM CaCl2, 20 mM imidazole (pH 6.8) at 22°C for 6 min or longer. Then, 15 μl of Solution A was mixed with 135 μl of Solution B containing various concentrations of potassium gluconate, sodium gluconate, 15 mM NaCl, 2.5 μM fluo-3, 20 mM imidazole (pH 6.8). Major ionic compositions of the priming Solution A and the depolarizing Solution B for each degree of ionic replacement (G1, G5.5, and G10; defined in the legend to Table 1) are given in Table 1. Inhibitors, when used, were included in Solution B. The time courses of SR Ca2+ release induced at various levels of depolarization were monitored with a stopped-flow fluorometer (BioLogic SFM-3 with MOS-200 optical system) using fluo-3 as a Ca2+ probe (excitation at 437 nm, emission at 530 nm with a 510-nm cut-off filter). Approximately 30-40 traces of the fluo-3 signal were averaged for each experiment.Tabled 1Fluorescence Assays of the Protein Conformational ChangeTo monitor the time course of depolarization-induced changes in the fluorescence intensity of the JFP-bound MCA probe, the fluorescently labeled triads (2.4 mg/ml) were incubated in Solution A, and 15 μl of the primed triads was mixed with 135 μl of Solution B devoid of fluo-3. The time courses of fluorescence change of the protein-bound MCA (excitation at 368 nm, emission at 440 nm using an interference filter with 70-nm bandwidth) induced by various degrees of depolarization were monitored with the same stopped-flow fluorometer. As a control, the fluorescently labeled triads were incubated in Solution A devoid of ATP (neither polarization of the T-tubule nor active Ca2+ loading of the SR), and the same mixing as above was performed. The control trace was subtracted from the traces of the polarized and depolarized sample. Approximately 70-90 traces of the MCA signal were averaged for each experiment.RESULTSWe produced various degrees of depolarization of the T-tubule moiety of the MCA-labeled triad using the previously described Na+-replacement protocol (see (17Ikemoto N. Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Morii M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 10961-10968Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar) and “Experimental Procedures”). The time courses of (a) depolarization-induced changes in the fluorescence intensity of the JFP-bound MCA probe and (b) depolarization-induced Ca2+ release from SR were monitored using stopped-flow fluorometry (Fig. 1). Although the Ca2+ release rate was slightly reduced after labeling, the voltage-dependent changes in the Ca2+ release kinetics (Fig. 1, rightpanel) show a pattern identical to that of the unlabeled triads described in our recent report(17Ikemoto N. Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Morii M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 10961-10968Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Thus, there was no Ca2+ release on dilution without ionic replacement (Fig. 1, G1). As the degree of ionic replacement and the concomitant T-tubule depolarization were increased, both the rate and the magnitude of Ca2+ release also increased. Fig. 1 also shows the corresponding time courses of the depolarization-induced changes in the fluorescence intensity of the JFP-attached MCA probe (ΔF). As seen, chemical depolarization produced a rapid increase in the fluoresecence intensity. The rate constant, as well as the amplitude of ΔF, increased again in a proportional fashion to the degree of ionic replacement, suggesting that rapid conformational change of the JFP reflected by the MCA fluorescence change is a phenomenon that is tightly coupled with both T-tubule depolarization and Ca2+ release. The rate constant of ΔF is significantly higher than that of Ca2+ release at each magnitude of T-tubule depolarization (cf. Table 2 and Table 3). Based on these results we propose that the depolarization signal transmitted from the T-tubule would produce first conformational changes in the JFP as manifested in ΔF, and subsequently activation of the release channel as illustrated in the following hypothesis. Nimodipine is one of the specific blockers of the DHP receptor/voltage sensor protein(23Bianchi C.P. Fed. Proc. 1968; 27: 126-131PubMed Google Scholar). Neomycin is another potent blocker of the T-tubule-to-SR communication, as evidenced by our recent finding that a low concentration of neomycin (0.1 μM) completely blocked Ca2+ release induced by chemical depolarization without affecting Ca2+ release induced by direct stimulation of the JFP moiety by polylysine(19Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Ikemoto N. FEBS Lett. 1994; 351: 349-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 2, either nimodipine (10 μM) or neomycin (0.1 μM) blocked both ΔF and SR Ca2+ release after depolarization, presumably by blocking Step 1 above. These results indicate that both the JFP conformational change and the subsequent SR Ca2+ release are under the control of the signal transmitted from the T-tubule. The results also suggest that blockage of the conformational change inevitably inhibits the subsequent release-activating step. The reference traces represent the time courses of MCA fluorescence change (leftpanel) and Ca2+ release (right panel) obtained with no added inhibitors, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)DISCUSSIONThe two major events in the skeletal muscle E-C coupling are (i) sensing of the membrane potential change (depolarization) by the DHPR of the T-tubule and (ii) activation of the SR Ca2+ release channel that resides in the JFP. However, little is known about how these events are coupled. In attempt to resolve the intermediate reaction steps involved in this coupling process, we incorporated the fluorescent conformational probe MCA into the JFP moiety of isolated triads in a site-directed manner and then investigated in parallel the conformational response of the JFP to the depolarization signal and the induced Ca2+ release from SR. The main findings are as follows. (a) The protein conformational change precedes SR Ca2+ release. (b) The voltage-dependent activation pattern of Ca2+ release is an identical copy of that of protein conformational change, suggesting that the mode of regulation of SR channel is already determined by the preceding protein conformational change. (c) Blockage of the signal transmission from the T-tubule to SR by nimodipine or neomycin inhibited the protein conformational change and, in turn, Ca2+ release; this suggests that both protein conformational change and Ca2+ release are induced by the signal derived from the T-tubule. (d) Inhibition by Mg2+ of the opening of the Ca2+ release channel (24Meissner G. Darling E. Eveleth J. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 236-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar, 25Pessah I. Francini A.O. Scales D.J. Waterhouse A.L. Casida J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 8643-8648Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) had virtually no effect on the protein conformational change, suggesting that the Mg2+ block of channel opening occurred after protein conformational change. From these results, we conclude that upon stimulation of the JFP via T-tubule, the JFP undergoes a transition from a state of lower MCA fluorescence (R) to another state (∗R) of higher MCA fluorescence, which in turn is followed by a third state (∗Ro) to open the channel. ↓R→ *R⇔ *Ro REACTION 2Low concentration of neomycin (e.g. 0.1 μM) blocks only depolarization-induced Ca2+ release(19Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Ikemoto N. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), caffeine(26Palade P. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6149-6154Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and Ca2+(26Palade P. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6149-6154Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 27Calviello G. Chiesi M. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 1301-1306Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). Thus, 0.1 μM neomycin works as a specific blocker of the signal transmission from T-tubule to SR(19Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Ikemoto N. FEBS Lett. 1994; 351: 349-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar), but at several micromolar it works as a channel blocker similar to Mg2+ and ruthenium red. Interestingly, no fluorescent labeling occurred when 0.1 μM neomycin was used as a carrier of SAED, and to obtain an appreciable level of specific labeling of the JFP the concentration of the carrier had to be increased to several μM, e.g. 2 μM, as done in the present study. Thus, the voltage-dependent fluorescence signal described in this study must have derived from the MCA probe attached to the channel-blocking neomycin-binding domain.As reported previously(16Kang J.J. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), the fluorescence intensity of the MCA probe incorporated into either the neomycin-binding or polylysine-binding domain of the JFP increased with increasing concentrations of Ca2+ in parallel to the activation of SR Ca2+ release. Furthermore, the JFP-specific Ca2+ release trigger polylysine induces an increase in the fluorescence of the MCA probe attached to either the neomycin or the polylysine domain, again paralleling the dose-dependent activation of SR Ca2+ release by polylysine. ( 2R. El-Hayek, M. Yano, and N. Ikemoto, unpublished data. )Together with the present finding that the kinetics of the JFP conformational change parallel the T-tubule depolarization, we propose that the conformational-switch mechanism proposed in (R →∗R) operates, as a common mechanism of channel activation, regardless of the type of Ca2+ release trigger (Ca2+, polylysine, or T-tubule depolarization).All the data shown in this paper were obtained with samples MCA-labeled at the neomycin-binding domain. According to our preliminary data, samples labeled at the polylysine-binding domain also show essentially the same voltage-dependent changes in MCA fluorescence as described here. Since neomycin and polylysine appear to bind to different domains (16Kang J.J. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), the JFP conformational change induced by these release triggers would be rather global.In conclusion, the present results suggest that the coupling between the T-tubule signal and SR Ca2+ release is mediated by a rapid conformational change of the JFP. The present study has opened a new way to resolve the intermediary reaction steps involved in the signal transmission/transduction processes. In order to further characterize the protein conformational change described here, however, several important problems remain to be investigated. These include the localization of the site of probe attachment in the primary and quaternary structures of the JFP and characterization of the structural significance of the observed fluorescence increase. This suggested that the JFP conformational change may play an important role in the regulation of various types of Ca2+ release. The main goal of this study is to investigate the hitherto merely hypothetical JFP conformational change during excitation-contraction (E-C) coupling by means of the MCA probe technique (16Kang J.J. Tarcsafalvi A. Carlos A.D. Fujimoto E. Shahrokh Z. Thevenin B.J.M. Shohet S.B. Ikemoto N. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3288-3293Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar) and of newly devised methods to produce voltage-controlled SR Ca2+ release in vitro(17Ikemoto N. Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Morii M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 10961-10968Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Here we report that chemical depolarization of the T-tubule moiety of the triad produces a rapid increase in the fluorescence intensity of the JFP-attached MCA probe (ΔF). The major findings are as follows. The rate of ΔF is much faster than that of Ca2+ release from the SR, indicating that the fluorescence change precedes Ca2+ release. Upon increasing the degree of ionic replacement, and thus the magnitude of T-tubule depolarization, both ΔF and the subsequent SR Ca2+ release increased in a parallel fashion. The DHP receptor antagonist nimodipine (cf. (18Rios E. Brum G. Nature. 1987; 325: 717-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar) or a novel blocker of the T-tubule-to-SR communication neomycin (19Yano M. El-Hayek R. Antoniu B. Ikemoto N. FEBS Lett. 1994; 351: 349-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar) inhibited both ΔF and SR Ca2+ release. However, blocking of Ca2+ release by 2 mM Mg2+ had virtually no effect on ΔF. These results suggest that depolarization-induced SR Ca2+ release is mediated by a conformational change of the JFP, which is a prerequisite of the activation of the Ca2+ release channel.

The mouse LINE-1 (L1) retrotransposon contains two open reading frames (ORFs). Three classes of the protein encoded by the first open reading frame (ORF1) are expressed in the mouse embryonal carcinoma cell line, F9; the apparent molecular sizes of these proteins are 41.3, 43, and 43.5 kDa. Two of these three proteins (41.3 and 43 kDa) are translated in vitro from full-length, sense-strand L1 RNA isolated from ribonucleoprotein particles. A reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction approach was used to clone the ORF1 region from RNA isolated from ribonucleoprotein particles, then the coding capacity of these clones was examined using in vitro transcription and translation. Multiple sequences that encode ORF1 were recovered by this approach, indicating that multiple loci of L1 in the mouse genome are expressed in F9 cells. In addition, L1 sequences with intact ORF1 regions appear to be selectively enriched in the ribonucleoprotein particles. The mouse LINE-1 (L1) retrotransposon contains two open reading frames (ORFs). Three classes of the protein encoded by the first open reading frame (ORF1) are expressed in the mouse embryonal carcinoma cell line, F9; the apparent molecular sizes of these proteins are 41.3, 43, and 43.5 kDa. Two of these three proteins (41.3 and 43 kDa) are translated in vitro from full-length, sense-strand L1 RNA isolated from ribonucleoprotein particles. A reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction approach was used to clone the ORF1 region from RNA isolated from ribonucleoprotein particles, then the coding capacity of these clones was examined using in vitro transcription and translation. Multiple sequences that encode ORF1 were recovered by this approach, indicating that multiple loci of L1 in the mouse genome are expressed in F9 cells. In addition, L1 sequences with intact ORF1 regions appear to be selectively enriched in the ribonucleoprotein particles.

The existence of multiple α, β, and γ subunits raises questions regarding the assembly of particular G proteins. Based on the results of a previous study (Rahmatullah, M., and Robishaw, J. D.(1994) J. Biol. Chem. 269, 3574-3580), we hypothesized that the assembly of G proteins may be determined by the interactions of the more structurally diverse α and γ subunits. This hypothesis was confirmed in the present study by showing striking differences in the abilities of the γ1 and γ2 subunits to interact with the the αo subunit. Chimeras of the γ1 and γ2 subunits were used to delineate which region is responsible. Support for the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit comes from our observations that 1) the γ2 subunit and the γ211 chimera bound strongly to the αo-agarose matrix, but the γ1 subunit and the γ112 chimera bound weakly, if at all; 2) an N-terminal peptide made to the γ2 subunit blocked the binding of the γ211 chimera to the αo-agarose matrix; 3) both the γ211 chimera and the N-terminal peptide were able to partially protect the αo subunit against tryptic cleavage; and 4) the γ211 chimera, but not the γ112 chimera, supported ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit. The existence of multiple α, β, and γ subunits raises questions regarding the assembly of particular G proteins. Based on the results of a previous study (Rahmatullah, M., and Robishaw, J. D.(1994) J. Biol. Chem. 269, 3574-3580), we hypothesized that the assembly of G proteins may be determined by the interactions of the more structurally diverse α and γ subunits. This hypothesis was confirmed in the present study by showing striking differences in the abilities of the γ1 and γ2 subunits to interact with the the αo subunit. Chimeras of the γ1 and γ2 subunits were used to delineate which region is responsible. Support for the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit comes from our observations that 1) the γ2 subunit and the γ211 chimera bound strongly to the αo-agarose matrix, but the γ1 subunit and the γ112 chimera bound weakly, if at all; 2) an N-terminal peptide made to the γ2 subunit blocked the binding of the γ211 chimera to the αo-agarose matrix; 3) both the γ211 chimera and the N-terminal peptide were able to partially protect the αo subunit against tryptic cleavage; and 4) the γ211 chimera, but not the γ112 chimera, supported ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit. The ability of cells to process a large number of extracellular signals into the appropriate array of intracellular responses depends on the types of signaling pathways that are expressed in the plasma membranes of these cells. The most common type of signaling pathway relies on the interaction of three kinds of proteins: receptors, heterotrimeric G proteins, ( 1The abbreviations used are: G proteinsa family of guanine nucleotide-binding proteinsGsαthe α subunit of Gs involved in stimulation of adenylylcyclaseGoαthe α subunit of GoDTTdithiothreitolLPXpolyoxyethylene 10-lauryl etherAMFaluminum, magnesium, and fluoride. )and effectors. The recent identification of more than 100 different types of receptors, more than 320 possible combinations of G protein heterotrimers, and an unknown number of effectors (1Birnbaumer L. Cell. 1992; 71: 1069-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (380) Google Scholar, 2Conklin B.R. Bourne H.R. Cell. 1993; 73: 631-641Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (388) Google Scholar) raises important questions as to how these signaling pathways are assembled to ensure the correct transmission of a signal from a particular receptor to a specific effector. Given its position between the receptor and the effector, it seems likely that much of the fidelity of signal transmission must reside in the αβ γ subunit structure of the G protein. a family of guanine nucleotide-binding proteins the α subunit of Gs involved in stimulation of adenylylcyclase the α subunit of Go dithiothreitol polyoxyethylene 10-lauryl ether aluminum, magnesium, and fluoride. While it has generally been assumed that a G protein should be defined on the basis of the α subunit, the rapidly growing number of different β and γ subunits suggests that a G protein should more properly be defined on the basis of its unique combination of αβ γ subunits. This idea is supported by antisense “knockout” studies by Kleuss et al.(3Kleuss C. Hescheler J. Ewel C. Rosenthal W. Schultz G. Wittig B. Nature. 1991; 353: 43-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar, 4Kleuss C. Scherubl H. Hescheler J. Schultz G. Wittig B. Nature. 1992; 358: 424-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar, 5Kleuss C. Hescheler J. Ewel C. Rosenthal W. Schultz G. Wittig B. Science. 1993; 259: 832-834Crossref PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar), demonstrating different combinations of G protein αβ γ subunits couple somatostatin and muscarinic receptors to inhibition of the same Ca2+ channel. However, since the α and the β γ subunits undergo an appreciable rate of dissociation in the course of detergent extraction and purification, it has not been possible to confirm the αβ γ composition of a particular G protein by biochemical studies. Furthermore, the tight association of the β γ subunits has not permitted the regions of the individual β and γ subunits that interact with the α subunits to be examined. In a previous paper(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we expressed the individual β and γ subunits in the baculovirus system and showed the direct association of the γ2 subunit with the α subunit of Go (αo subunit). This result suggested the possibility that selective association of the γ and α subunits might provide the mechanistic basis for the assembly of particular G protein αβ γ subunit combinations. With the recent identification of at least 10 different γ subunits ( 2We have recently identified 3 new γ subunits, bringing the total number of known γ subunits to 10 (J. D. Robishaw, unpublished results). )(7Cali J.J. Balcueva E.A. Rybalkin I. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 24023-24027Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and with their expression in the baculovirus system, it is now possible to examine the specificity of α and γ subunit interactions in a systematic fashion. In the present paper, we show differential association of the γ1 and γ2 subunits with the αo subunit. Furthermore, we identify the N-terminal 15 amino acids of the γ subunit as the region responsible for conferring the specificity of association with the α subunit, using a combination of peptide and chimeric approaches. The coding regions of the β1, γ1, γ2, γ3, and γ5 cDNAs were subcloned into the pVL1392 or pVL1393 transfer vectors as previously described(8Robishaw J.D. Kalman V.K. Proulx K.L. Biochem. J. 1992; 286: 677-680Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar, 9Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Simon M.I. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4388-4395Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Using a combination of restriction enzyme digestion and polymerase chain reaction, the chimeric γ112 cDNA was generated by replacing the C-terminal 23 amino acid residues of the γ1 subunit with the corresponding 23 amino acid residues of the γ2 subunit, while the chimeric γ211 cDNA was produced by replacing the N-terminal 18 amino acid residues of the γ1 subunit with the corresponding 15 amino acid residues of the γ2 subunit. Following polymerase chain reaction amplification, the chimeric γ112 and γ211 cDNAs were subcloned into the pVL1392 transfer vector. Transfer of the cDNAs from this transfer vector to the wild type Autographa californica nuclear polyhedrosis virus genome and plaque purification of the resulting recombinant viruses were performed as previously described(8Robishaw J.D. Kalman V.K. Proulx K.L. Biochem. J. 1992; 286: 677-680Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar, 9Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Simon M.I. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4388-4395Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The recombinant viruses were used to infect Spodoptera frugiperda (Sf9) cells at a multiplicity of infection of 2. The Sf9 cells were grown in monolayers or spinners in TNM-FH medium containing 10% fetal calf serum at 27°C. The αo subunit was purified from bovine brain as previously described by Sternweis and Robishaw(11Sternweis P.C. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 13806-13813Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The αs subunit was obtained as a side product of the αo purification. Elution fractions from the C-7 column enriched in the αs subunit were pooled, concentrated on an Amicon ultrafiltration device with a PM-10 membrane, and then dialyzed for 16 h with 2 changes against buffer A (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 8), 0.1 M NaCl, 6 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 10 mM sodium, 10 μM AlCl3, 1 mM DTT, and 0.3% cholate). Further purification of the αs subunit on octyl-Sepharose was performed as previously described(12Sohma H. Hashimoto H. Ohguro H. Akino T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 184: 175-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). The β1 γ3 and β1 γ5 dimers were purified from the particulate fractions of baculovirus-infected Sf9 cells using αo affinity and hydroxyapatite chromatography as previously described(9Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Simon M.I. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23409-23417Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Ueda N. Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Lee E. Smrcka A.V. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4388-4395Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Elution fractions containing the β1 γ3 and β1 γ5 dimers were pooled and concentrated. Prior to use in ADP-ribosylation assays, the β1 γ3 and β1 γ5 dimers were dialyzed against two changes of buffer B (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 8), 1.6 mM DTT, 1 mM EDTA, and 0.05% LPX). Approximately 68 h after infection, the cells were collected from 1-liter spinner flasks by centrifugation (3,000 × g for 10 min), rinsed with phosphate-buffered saline, and resuspended in 40 ml of buffer C (20 mM Na-HEPES (pH 8), 2 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT, 0.1 mM 4-(2-aminoethyl)-benzenesulfonylfluoride, and 1 mM benzamidine). The cells were lysed by Parr bombing at 500 p.s.i. for 45 min at 4°C and then stirred gently on an orbital shaker for 3 h at the same temperature. The supernatants were collected by centrifugation (100,000 × g for 30 min) and designated as the cytoplasmic fraction. The pellets were dissolved in 40 ml of buffer C containing 1% cholate for 16 h at 4°C by stirring on an orbital shaker. Any insoluble material was discarded by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 30 min. The supernatant from the last centrifugation was designated as the particulate fraction. To prepare the αo-affinity resin, approximately 30 mg of the purified αo subunit was coupled to 15 ml of ω-aminobutyl-agarose as described by Mumby et al.(13Mumby S.M. Casey P.J. Gilman A.G. Gutowski S. Sternweis P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 5873-5877Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). The resin was washed extensively with buffer D (20 mM Na-HEPES (pH 8), 400 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT, and 5 μM GDP) containing 0.5% LPX prior to packing into a Pharmacia XK 16/20 column. To measure binding to the αo-affinity resin, we loaded equivalent amounts of the expressed γ subunits based on immunoblotting of cytosolic and particulate fractions with the same antibody, immunoblotting conditions, and exposures for detection. Accordingly, a 3-ml aliquot of the cytosolic and particulate fractions from γ211- and γ1-infected cells or a 1-ml aliquot from γ112-infected cells was diluted 10-fold with buffer D containing 0.05% LPX and then loaded onto the αo-affinity column at a flow rate of 0.3 ml/min. The column was then washed successively with 2 column volumes of buffer D containing 0.5% LPX at a flow rate of 0.9 ml/min and 20 column volumes of buffer D containing 0.05% LPX at a flow rate of 1.8 ml/min. The column was then eluted with buffer E (20 mM Na-HEPES (pH 8), 400 mM NaCl, 2 mM DTT, 20 mM MgCl2, 10 mM sodium, 5 μM GDP, and 30 μM AlCl3) at a flow rate of 0.3 ml/min. The AMF elution fractions containing the γ subunits were pooled, concentrated, and then measured for protein concentration using the Amido Black assay. To evaluate the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit, a series of peptides made to the various regions of the γ1 and γ2 subunits were synthesized. To examine the effect of these peptides on γ2 or γ211 binding, the αo-agarose matrix was pre-equilibrated with about 1 μmol of each of these peptides. This amount of each of the peptides was estimated to be 100-fold higher than the amount of γ2 or γ211 loaded on the matrix, taking into account the possibility that the shorter sequence of the peptides might not be optimal toward adopting full conformation for binding to the αo subunit. Tryptic proteolysis assays were conducted with the αo or αs subunits in the presence or absence of the purified γ chimeras. Unless indicated otherwise, to 20 μl of assay buffer was added 10 μl of αo or αs subunits and up to 48 μl of the chimeric γ subunits (an equivalent amount of elution buffer concentrate from a mock αo-affinity column run was used as a control). The volume was brought up to 90 μl with water, and the mixture was incubated at 4°C for 30 min followed by room temperature incubation for 10 min. Proteolysis was initiated by addition of 10 μl of trypsin at a constant protein to trypsin ratio of 50:1 and incubation at 30°C. The final assay mix contained 35 mM Na-HEPES (pH 8), 300 mM NaCl, 2 mM DTT, 10 mM MgCl2, 40 mM EDTA, 5 μM GDP, and 0.1% LPX. We found that this high concentration of EDTA was necessary due to the presence of AMF in the fractions utilized in these studies. 20-μl aliquots were withdrawn at timed intervals, and reactions were terminated by adding 15 μl of 2.3 × Laemmli sample buffer (containing 23 mM benzamidine) and boiling for 5 min at 90°C. The procedure used was a modification of that described by Casey et al.(14Casey P.J. Graziano M.P. Gilman A.G. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 611-616Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). To 10 μl of stock assay buffer was added 5 μl of purified αo and up to 20 μl of β γ dimers or 10 μl of chimeric γ subunits. An appropriate volume of β γ dialysis buffer or γ elution buffer was added to all samples to give equivalent concentrations of all reagents. The final concentrations of all reagents were 60 mM Tris-Cl (pH 8.0), 0.8 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 5 mM MgCl2, 80 μM GDP, 80 μM NaCl, 0.04% LPX, 2 mM NaF, 6 μM AlCl3, 2 μM NAD, [32P]NAD (12,000-15,000 cpm/pmol), 0.4 mM dimyristoylphosphatidylcholine, and 4 μg/ml pertussis toxin. Reactions were initiated by addition of [32P]NAD and pertussis toxin and were allowed to proceed at 30°C. Aliquots of 20 μl were withdrawn at 20 and 40 min of incubation, added to 20 μl of Laemmli 2 × sample buffer, and boiled for 5 min. Following SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis on 15% gels, ADP-ribosylation was visualized by autoradiography of dried gels. To follow the purification of the chimeric γ subunits, the proteins in the various chromatographic fractions were resolved by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis on 15% acrylamide gels and transferred to nitrocellulose for immunoblotting as previously described(15Robishaw J.D. Balcueva E.A. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 208: 283-287Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 16Robishaw J.D. Balcueva E.A. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 237: 498-507Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). For immunoblotting, the antibody A-4 was used at a 1:500 dilution to detect γ1, γ112, and γ211. The antibodies A-10, 584, U-49, B-17, B-53, and D-10 were used at a 1:500 dilution to detect the αo, αs, β1, γ2, γ3, and γ5 subunits, respectively, as previously described (16Robishaw J.D. Balcueva E.A. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 237: 498-507Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 17Mumby S.M. Gilman A.G. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 195: 215-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 18Robishaw J.D. Smigel M.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9587-9590Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The αo, β, and γ antibodies were detected with 125I-labeled goat anti-rabbit F(ab′)2 fragment (DuPont NEN) (1 × 106 cpm/ml). The αs antibody was detected using horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG chemiluminescent probe (Amersham Corp.). Previously, we reported that the γ2 subunit can stably interact with the αo subunit of G proteins(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This interaction was markedly enhanced by prenylation of the γ2 subunit but was not dependent on the presence of the β subunit. This result raised the possibility that selective interaction of particular α and γ subunits may provide the mechanistic basis for the assembly of specific αβ γ combinations of the G proteins. This possibility was confirmed in the present paper by showing marked differences in the abilities of the γ1 and γ2 subunits, which are only 36% identical at the amino acid level(19Robishaw J.D. Kalman V.K. Moomaw C. Slaughter C.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15758-15761Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), to interact with the αo subunit (Fig. 1). To try to delineate the region(s) of the γ subunit responsible for determining the selective interaction with the αo subunit, chimeras were constructed to look for “gain of function” by replacing regions of the γ1 subunit with the γ2 subunit. For the γ112 chimera, the C-terminal 23 amino acid residues of γ1 were replaced with the corresponding 23 residues of the γ2 subunit (Fig. 2). This region was chosen since previous papers (6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Simon M.I. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23409-23417Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) showed that prenylation of the γ subunit was shown to be necessary for stable interaction with the α subunit, suggesting a potential involvement of the C-terminal region of the γ subunit in α- γ interaction. For the γ211 chimera, the N-terminal 18 amino acid residues of γ1 were replaced with the corresponding 15 residues of the γ2 subunit. This region was selected since it was the most diverse at the amino acid level, suggesting the N-terminal region of the γ subunit as a possible site of interaction with the structurally diverse α subunits(19Robishaw J.D. Kalman V.K. Moomaw C. Slaughter C.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15758-15761Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To direct the expression of the chimeric and wild type γ subunits, Sf9 cells were infected with recombinant baculoviruses encoding either the γ1, γ112, or γ211 subunits. Approximately 68 h after infection, the cytosolic and particulate fractions were prepared from these cells for analysis. The cytosolic and particulate fractions were analyzed separately since prenylated forms of the γ1, γ112, and γ211 subunits have been found in both fractions. ( 3A paper reporting the specificity and functional consequences of prenylation of the γ1 subunit expressed in the baculovirus system has been submitted for publication. )It was previously shown that only the prenylated forms of the γ subunits have the potential to interact with the α subunit(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To monitor α- γ association, the chimeric and wild type γ subunits from either the cytosolic or particulate fraction were loaded onto an αo-agarose column under conditions favoring subunit association (i.e. in the presence of GDP)(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After extensive washing, the γ subunits were selectively eluted from the αo-agarose column under conditions favoring subunit dissociation (i.e. in the presence of AMF). To follow their binding and selective elution, an antibody raised to a peptide common to the γ1, γ112, and γ211 subunits was used (depicted by the stippledareas in Fig. 2). A consequence of utilizing the same antibody to detect both the chimeric and wild type proteins was that roughly equivalent amounts of the γ1, γ112, and γ211 subunits could be loaded, allowing their relative affinities for the αo subunit to be differentiated. The elution profiles of the cytosolic and particulate fractions from γ1-infected cells are shown in Fig. 3. Both the cytosolic and particulate forms of the γ1 subunit were detected in the flow through and 0.5% Lubrol wash fractions (lanes2 and 3) but not in the subsequent 0.05% Lubrol wash fractions (lanes4-7) or AMF elution fractions (8-18) (panelsA and B, topinsert). The elution profiles of the cytosolic and particulate fractions from γ112-infected cells were similar. Using the same immunoblotting conditions that were used for the detection of the γ1 subunit, both the cytosolic and particulate forms of the γ112 chimera were detected in the flow through and 0.5% Lubrol wash fractions (lanes2 and 3) but not in the AMF elution fractions (lanes8-18) (panelsA and B, middleinserts). However, after prolonged exposure of the autoradiogram for 5 days, we observed a low but detectable amount of the particulate form of the γ112 chimera in the AMF elution fractions (data not shown). The presence of the γ112 chimera was further confirmed by concentration of the AMF elution fractions followed by detection with antisera. The same procedure failed to detect either the cytosolic or particulate form of the γ1 subunit in the AMF elution fractions (data not shown). Taken together, these results suggest that the γ1 subunit shows no detectable binding to the αo-agarose matrix, while the γ112 chimera shows very low binding. In contrast, the elution profiles of the cytosolic and particulate fractions from γ211 chimera-infected cells were markedly different (Fig. 3). Using the same immunoblotting conditions that were used for the detection of the γ1 and γ112 subunits, a significant portion of the cytosolic form of the γ211 chimera was stably retained on the αo-agarose matrix and specifically eluted with buffer containing AMF (panelA, bottominsert). Interestingly, elution with AMF appeared to result in the resolution of the cytosolic form of the γ211 chimera into two peaks (lanes8-9 and 13-16, respectively). Although the reason for this is not known, the two peaks may be related to the nature of the prenyl group. In support of this possibility, we showed that the cytosolic form of the γ1 subunit is modified by both farnesyl and geranylgeranyl moieties when expressed in Sf9 cells.3 Since the γ211 chimera contains the prenylation recognition sequence of the γ1 subunit, it is likely that the γ211 chimera is similarly modified by both farnesyl and geranylgeranyl groups. Thus, the two peaks may represent forms of the γ211 chimera with different prenyl moieties. Likewise, a significant portion of the particulate form of the γ211 chimera was also selectively retained and specifically eluted with AMF (panelB, bottominsert). However, unlike the cytosolic form, the particulate form of the γ211 chimera was eluted in a single peak (lanes8-10). Again, this may be related to the nature of the prenyl group and/or the extent of carboxyl methylation.3 Nevertheless, it is clear from these results that replacement of the N-terminal 18 amino acids of the γ1 subunit with the corresponding 15 amino acids of the γ2 subunit is sufficient to confer the specificity of interaction with the αo-agarose matrix. To further examine the role of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit in specifying interaction with the α subunit, two peptides corresponding to different regions of the γ2 subunit were synthesized. Peptide 1 contained the sequence ASNNTASIAQARK corresponding to amino acid residues 2-14 of the γ2 subunit, while peptide 2 contained the sequence DLMAYSEAHAK corresponding to amino acid residues 35-46 of the γ2 subunit(19Robishaw J.D. Kalman V.K. Moomaw C. Slaughter C.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15758-15761Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Following equilibration of the α0-agarose matrix with each peptide, the selective retention and AMF-dependent elution of the γ211 chimera was monitored. As shown in Fig. 4, in the presence of peptide 1, the proportion of γ211 chimera that was bound and eluted with AMF was drastically reduced (panelB). In contrast, peptide 2 corresponding to the middle region of the γ2 subunit resulted in little apparent reduction in the proportion of the γ211 chimera that was bound and selectively eluted from the column, although the pattern of elution was altered somewhat (compare panelsC and A). Peptides 1 and 2 had similiar effects on the binding of the γ2 subunit (data not shown). Taken together, the marked difference in the abilities of the peptides 1 and 2 to inhibit the interaction of the γ211 chimera and γ2 subunit with the αo-agarose matrix underscores the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit for interaction with the α subunit. Interestingly, the middle region of the γ subunit has been implicated in the interaction with the β subunit (20Spring D.J. Neer E.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22882-22886Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Previously, we showed that the γ2 subunit, in the absence of the β subunit, could protect the αo subunit against tryptic cleavage(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Accordingly, we examined whether the γ211 and γ112 chimeras could protect the αo subunit from tryptic cleavage. Because of the presence of AMF in the purified preparations of the γ211 and γ112 chimeras, tryptic digestions were carried out in the presence of a high concentration of EDTA. As shown in Fig. 5, tryptic cleavage of the 39-kDa αo subunit (lane1) generated a 37-kDa fragment (panelA, lane2) in the absence of any γ subunit. Interestingly, the addition of the γ211 chimera was able to partially protect the αo subunit against tryptic cleavage with increasing protection observed as the γ211 to αo ratio was raised from 0.25:1 up to 2:1 (lanes3-6). On the other hand, the addition of the γ112 chimera offered little or no protection even at the highest molar ratio of 2:1 (compare lane6 of each). These results confirm the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit in promoting α- γ interaction. However, it should be noted that the γ211 chimera was less effective at protecting the αo subunit than the wild type γ2 subunit. At a stoichiometry of 2:1, the wild type γ2 subunit was found to fully protect the αo subunit against tryptic proteolysis(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Whether this difference is indicative of other regions of the γ subunit being involved in the protection of the αo subunit against trypsin or a reflection of lower affinity for the αo subunit because of the chimeric nature of γ211 remains to be established. We also decided to examine whether the addition of the γ211 chimera was equally able to protect the α subunit of Gs (αs subunit) against tryptic cleavage. As shown in panelB of Fig. 5, the αs subunit (lane1) was digested rapidly by trypsin (lane2). Moreover, even at the highest stoichiometry of γ211 to αs of 2:1 (lane6), the γ211 chimera showed no protection of the αs subunit against tryptic proteolysis. Taken together, these results eliminate the possibility of the γ subunit acting as an inhibitor of trypsin, and as such, protecting the α subunit. More importantly, these results suggest that structural differences in the α subunits as well as the γ subunits are critical in specifying their interactions. Since peptide 1 corresponding to amino acid residues 2-14 of the γ2 subunit was able to inhibit the binding of the γ211 chimera to the αo-agarose matrix (Fig. 4A), we decided to evaluate the possible effect of this peptide to protect the αo subunit against tryptic proteolysis. By way of comparison, peptide 3 corresponding to amino acid residues 2-15 of the γ1 subunit was also evaluated. As shown in Fig. 6, the αo subunit (lane1) was digested to 37- and 24- kDa fragments (lane2). Increasing concentrations of peptide 1 resulted in greater protection of the 39-kDa band and correspondingly less generation of the 37- and 24-kDa fragments (lanes3 and 4). In contrast, peptide 3 showed no protection of the 39-kDa band over the same concentration range (lanes5 and 6). Taken together, these results demonstrate a specific interaction between peptide 1 and the αo subunit. However, it should be noted that a 24:1 stoichiometry of peptide 1 to αo afforded less protection against tryptic proteolysis than a 2:1 stoichiometry of γ211 chimera to αo. The higher stoichiometry required for peptide 1 compared with γ211 chimera may reflect the involvement of other regions of the γ subunit in interaction with the α subunit. Alternatively, other regions of the γ subunit may reduce the number of possible conformations, thereby increasing the proportion of the γ subunit in the correct conformation for interaction with α subunit. The β γ dimers have been shown to support the pertussis toxin-dependent ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit(14Casey P.J. Graziano M.P. Gilman A.G. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 611-616Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). Accordingly, we decided to evaluate the ability of the γ211 and γ112 chimeras to promote ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit. Somewhat to our surprise, the γ211 chimera was able to support ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit (lanes8-11) though not to the extent observed with either the β1 γ3 dimer (lanes2-4) or the β1 γ5 dimer (lanes 5-7) at 15-fold lower concentrations (Fig. 7). Nevertheless, the ability of the γ211 chimera to support ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit appeared to be real since increasing concentrations of γ211 resulted in increasing ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit (lanes 8-11versus control in lane1). On the other hand, the γ112 chimera failed to support ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit over the same concentration range (lanes 12-15). The existence of multiple α, β, and γ subunits, many of which are expressed in the same tissue, raises questions regarding the assembly of G proteins with distinct roles in receptor-effector coupling. Hypothetically, the assembly of particular combinations of α, β, and γ subunits might be regulated by differential expression of these subunits in various cell types and/or differential affinities of these subunits to associate with each other. If we extrapolate from previous findings on β- γ (21Pronin A.N. Gautam N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 6220-6224Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar, 22Schmidt C.J. Thomas T.C. Levine M.A. Neer E.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 13807-13810Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and α- γ (6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) interactions, it seems likely that the assembly of particular combinations of α, β, and γ subunits may be determined by their differential affinities. It further seems plausible that functional diversity of the G proteins may be conferred by the specific assembly of the more structurally diverse α and γ subunits rather than the less structurally diverse β subunits. This hypothesis was confirmed in the present study by showing striking differences in the abilities of the structurally diverse γ1 and γ2 subunits to interact with the αo subunit. In the present study, we have used chimeras of the γ1 and γ2 subunits to identify which region specifies interaction with the α subunit. Support for the importance of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit comes from our observations that 1) the γ2 subunit and the γ211 chimera bound strongly to the αo-agarose matrix, but the γ1 subunit and the γ112 chimera bound only weakly, if at all; 2) a, N-terminal peptide corresponding to amino acids 2-14 of the γ2 subunit blocked the binding of the γ2 subunit and the γ211 chimera to the αo-agarose matrix, but an internal peptide corresponding to amino acids 35-46 of the γ2 subunit had little effect on binding; 3) the γ211 chimera and the N-terminal peptide were able to partially protect the αo subunit against tryptic cleavage; and 4) the γ211 chimera was able to partially support the ADP-ribosylation of the αo subunit, but the γ112 chimera had no such effect. Taken together, these results strongly indicate that the N-terminal region of the γ subunit plays the determinant role in conferring the specificity of interaction with a particular α subunit. In an earlier report(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we showed that prenylation of the γ subunit is important for α- γ interaction. The present results extend that observation. Following expression in Sf9 insect cells, the γ2 subunit is modified exclusively by a geranylgeranyl moiety, whereas the γ1 subunit is modified by farnesyl and geranylgeranyl moieties in roughly equal proportions.3 Nevertheless, even though a significant proportion of the γ1 subunit is modified by a geranylgeranyl group, the γ1 subunit cannot interact with αo subunit within the limits of detection. Thus, the N-terminal region of the γ subunit rather than prenylation of the C-terminal region plays the primary role in determining the specificity of the α- γ interaction. However, it is possible that the nature of prenyl group may play a secondary role in determining the specificity and/or stability of the α- γ interaction. Nevertheless, it is clear from these studies (6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) that both a favorable N-terminal region and a prenylated C-terminal region of the γ subunit are needed for optimal α- γ association. Interestingly, a recent study by Neer and Spring (20Spring D.J. Neer E.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22882-22886Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) has implicated the middle region of the γ subunit in determining the specificity of β- γ interaction. Taken together, these results would predict a model in which the N- and C-terminal regions of the γ subunit come together to form the face for α interaction while the middle region forms the opposing face for β interaction. The results of the present study support the computer-based prediction of the N-terminal regions of both α and γ subunits as their possible sites of interaction. In this regard, a computer-based analysis of coiled coil forming probabilities has led to the hypothesis that G protein heterotrimers form via triple-stranded coiled coil interactions involving the N-terminal regions of the α, β, and γ subunits(23Lupas A.N. Lupas J.M. Stock J.B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 105-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). However, this is the first experimental evidence to support the involvement of the N-terminal region of the γ subunit in this interaction. In a previous study(6Rahmatullah M. Robishaw J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3574-3580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we observed that the β subunit, when expressed by itself, cannot bind to the αo-agarose matrix. Thus, the γ subunit appears to be necessary for conferring this binding. On the other hand, the highest coiled coil forming probabilities are present in the N-terminal domains of the β subunits, with the N-terminal domains of the α and γ subunits being more variable(23Lupas A.N. Lupas J.M. Stock J.B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 105-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Certainly, the formation of a double-stranded coiled coil between the β and γ subunits could be further stabilized on formation of a triple-stranded coiled coil with the α subunit. Since the β γ subunits exist as a dimer in the physiological state, one possible role for the β subunit may be to confer additional stability to the heterotrimer. Another possible role for the β subunit may be to allow conformational flexibility within the β γ dimer enabling further interaction with the α subunit. For instance, the γ1 subunit cannot bind to the αo subunit. However, the γ1 subunit in association with the β1 subunit can bind to the αo subunit(9Iñiguez-Lluhi J.A. Simon M.I. Robishaw J.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23409-23417Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In future studies, we will express the chimeric γ subunits with the various β subunits and study their combined interactions with the α subunit. It is expected that such results will eventually provide the mechanistic basis for G protein heterotrimer formation. We thank Dr. Jim Cali for construction of chimeras, Vivian Kalman and Marilyn Pray for baculovirus expression, Barbara Rabold for peptide synthesis, and Eric Balcueva for immuno-blotting. Also, we thank Dr. Carl Hansen and Dr. Howard Morgan for reading the manuscript and helpful suggestions.

We have characterized the internalization and down-regulation of the insulin receptor and nine receptors with mutations in the transmembrane (TM) domain and/or flanking charged amino acids to define the role of this domain in receptor cycling. When expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, all had normal tetrameric structure and normal insulin-stimulated autophosphorylation/kinase activity. Replacement of the TM domain with that of the platelet-derived growth factor receptor, insertion of 3 amino acids, and substitution of Asp for Val938 or of Ala for either Gly933 or Pro934 had no effect on internalization. Replacement of the TM domain with that of c-neu or conversion of the charged amino acids on the cytoplasmic flank to uncharged amino acids, on the other hand, resulted in a 40-60% decrease in insulin-dependent internalization rate constants. By contrast, substitution of Ala for both Gly933 and Pro934 increases lateral diffusion mobility and accelerates internalization rate. These changes in internalization were due to decreased or increased rates of redistribution of receptors from microvilli to the nonvillous cell surface. In all cases, receptor down-regulation and receptor-mediated insulin degradation paralleled the changes in internalization. Thus, the structure of the transmembrane domain of the insulin receptor and flanking amino acids are major determinants of receptor internalization, insulin degradation, and receptor down-regulation. We have characterized the internalization and down-regulation of the insulin receptor and nine receptors with mutations in the transmembrane (TM) domain and/or flanking charged amino acids to define the role of this domain in receptor cycling. When expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, all had normal tetrameric structure and normal insulin-stimulated autophosphorylation/kinase activity. Replacement of the TM domain with that of the platelet-derived growth factor receptor, insertion of 3 amino acids, and substitution of Asp for Val938 or of Ala for either Gly933 or Pro934 had no effect on internalization. Replacement of the TM domain with that of c-neu or conversion of the charged amino acids on the cytoplasmic flank to uncharged amino acids, on the other hand, resulted in a 40-60% decrease in insulin-dependent internalization rate constants. By contrast, substitution of Ala for both Gly933 and Pro934 increases lateral diffusion mobility and accelerates internalization rate. These changes in internalization were due to decreased or increased rates of redistribution of receptors from microvilli to the nonvillous cell surface. In all cases, receptor down-regulation and receptor-mediated insulin degradation paralleled the changes in internalization. Thus, the structure of the transmembrane domain of the insulin receptor and flanking amino acids are major determinants of receptor internalization, insulin degradation, and receptor down-regulation. In this study, we have examined the role of the transmembrane domain and flanking charged amino acids of the insulin receptor in ligand-dependent receptor internalization utilizing a series of nine mutant insulin receptors in which these domains were modified by in vitro mutagenesis. Although these mutants have normal insulin-stimulated receptor kinase activity and an intact juxtamembrane region, using a combination of biochemical and morphological techniques, we find that several of these mutants exhibit decreased insulin-stimulated internalization and one exhibits accelerated internalization. Furthermore, these mutations in the transmembrane domain affect receptor down-regulation and receptor-mediated insulin degradation. Thus, the TM domain and the flanking charged amino acids provide an important determinant of ligand-dependent internalization of the insulin receptor and subsequent receptor down-regulation and ligand degradation. 125I-Insulin was prepared to a specific activity of 3000 Ci/mol at the Peptide Synthesis Core, Joslin Diabetes Center. Cells were lysed in 0.1 N NaOH, 0.1% SDS, and the radioactivity was counted to determine total cell-associated insulin, i.e. the counts/minutes remaining after the neutral wash, and internalized insulin, i.e. the 125I-insulin remaining after the acidic wash(13Backer J.M. The internalization rate constant (Ke) was calculated based on the internalization data as described by Lund et al.(27Lund K.A. Opresko L.K. Starbuck C. Walsh B.J. Wiley H.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 15713-15723Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and Backer et al.(28Backer J.M. Shoelson S.E. Haring E. White M.F. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1535-1545Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). Briefly, the instantaneous velocity of ligand internalization was expressed as dLint/dt = Ke[LRs], where Lint is the amount of internalized ligand and [LRs] is the concentration of cell-surface ligand-receptor complex. Integrating both sides of the equation, Lint = Ke[LRs]dt. Thus, the Ke is the slope of the line when Lint is plotted versus [LRs] as a function of time. Integrals were approximated by the trapezoidal rule taking an interval of dt = 2 min. Fixed cells from two different experiences were dehydrated, processed for electron microscopy autoradiography, and quantitated as described previously(8Carpentier J.L. Gorden P. Amherdt M. Van Obberghen E. Kahn C.R. Orci L. J. Clin. Invest. 1978; 61: 1057-1070Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. For each incubation time, three Epon blocks were prepared, and three sections were cut from each block. Thus, for each time point studied for each cell line, 18 separate grids were examined, out of which 1000-2000 grains were analyzed from all cells judged to be morphologically intact. Grains within a distance of 250 nm from the plasma membrane were considered associated with the cell surface, whereas grains overlying the cytoplasm and >250 nm from the plasma membrane were considered internalized. Grains associated with the plasma membrane were divided into the following classes: 1) microvilli, 2) coated pits, 3) nonvillous noncoated pits segments, and 4) uninterpretable. Grains were considered associated with microvilli or coated pits if their center was <250 nm from these surface domains; they were categorized as uninterpretable when the structures underlying the grain could not be unequivocally identified. Confluent CHO cells in 24-well plates were incubated with 125I-insulin (100,000 cpm/well) for 18 h at 4°C. Cells were washed twice with chilled PBS and quickly warmed to 37°C by addition of 0.5 ml of internalization medium to each well. At the indicated times, aliquots of medium were taken and mixed with an equal volume of 15% trichloroacetic acid to give a final trichloroacetic acid concentration of 7.5%. The intact insulin was precipitated by centrifugation in a microcentrifuge, and the radioactivity in the supernatant was counted to determine the amount of degraded insulin. Data are expressed as the ratio of degraded insulin to that initially bound to the cells. Confluent CHO cells in 24-well plates were incubated with or without 10-7M insulin at 37°C for the indicated times in 0.5 ml of internalization medium/well. After incubation, the medium was aspirated, and the cells were washed twice with chilled PBS, pH 3.5, supplemented with 0.3% bovine serum albumin and then twice with PBS, 0.3% bovine serum albumin, pH 7.4, to remove all surface-bound insulin. Each wash included a 3-min incubation. To quantify cell-surface insulin receptors, cells were incubated with either 0.1 ng/ml 125I-insulin and unlabeled insulin or iodinated monoclonal antibody 83-14 (200,000 cpm/well) in 0.5 ml of internalization medium/well at 4°C. After 18 h of incubation, cells were washed twice with chilled PBS, pH 7.4, and digested in 0.1 N NaOH, 0.1% SDS, and the associated radioactivity was counted in an automated γ-counter. In some experiments, cells were preincubated with insulin in the presence of 50 mM monensin, followed by cell-surface receptor quantification. The mutants used in this study include entire replacements of the TM domain by TM domains of the proto-oncoprotein c-neu (TM/c-neu) or the platelet-derived growth factor receptor (TM/PDGFR), an aspartic acid substitution for Val938 (TM-D/V) analogous to the point mutation in the neu oncoprotein, an insertion of the 3 amino acids Val-Phe-Leu between Leu940 and Phe941, double alanine substitutions for Gly933 and Pro934, single alanine substitutions for either Gly933 or Pro934, and replacements of 3 flanking charged amino acids at the intracellular face of the TM domain (Arg953-Lys954-Arg955) with the uncharged amino acids Ala-Asn-Ala with or without insertion of Arg-Lys-Arg into the exofacial surface of the TM domain (++++exo/cyt and +exo/cyt, respectively). The sequences of all of these mutant TM domains are shown in Fig. 1. CHO cells stably transfected with cDNAs for normal and mutant insulin receptors expressed between 2.5 × 105 and 3.6 × 106 binding sites/cell (Table 1). Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1535-1545Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) (Fig. 4). The Ke values for TM domain mutants TM/c-neu, +exo/cyt, and ++++exo/cyt were decreased by 40-60% as compared with that of the wild-type receptor (Fig. 4). The Ala1030 mutant, which has abolished tyrosine kinase activation, showed the lowest level internalization rate (Ke ~ 15% of the wild-type Ke). On the other hand, the TM-AA/GP insulin receptor mutant, in which 2 naturally occurring helix-breaking amino acids (Gly933 and Pro934) were replaced with 2 helix-favoring alanines, was found to have an accelerated insulin uptake rate corresponding to ~70% above that of the wild-type receptor (Fig. 4, A, rightpanel, opensquares; and B). All other mutant receptors showed a normal insulin uptake rate (Figure 3:, Figure 4:). Two surface steps precede the entry of insulin receptors inside the cells: the first is ligand-specific and consists of the insulin-induced redistribution of the receptor from microvilli to the nonvillous domain of the cell surface; the second is ligand-independent and common to many receptors and consists of the anchoring of receptors to clathrin-coated pits, which represent the internalization gate(16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 118: 831-839Google Scholar). To distinguish whether the modified rates of internalization observed with the various insulin receptor TM domain mutants were related to altered surface events, we analyzed morphologically the surface localization and redistribution of these receptors. With respect to the first step, both the TM/c-neu and ++++exo/cyt mutants exhibited defects in internalization and redistributed from microvilli to the nonvillous region of the cell surface in response to 125I-insulin binding more slowly and to a lesser extent than wild-type receptors, but faster than the Ala1030 mutant receptors (Fig. 5). By contrast, the TM-AA/GP mutant receptor, which exhibited an increased internalization rate, was more rapidly redistributed than the normal human insulin receptor (Fig. 5). With respect to the second step of internalization, the anchoring in clathrin-coated pits, the TM/c-neu and ++++exo/cyt mutants exhibited a reduced association with these surface areas when all surface-associated autoradiographic grains localizing 125I-insulin were considered (Fig. 6A). However, if we considered only labeled material present on the nonvillous cell surface, these receptor mutants showed the same propensity to associate with clathrin-coated pits (Fig. 6B). Thus, these mutants are able to anchor to clathrin-coated pits, but are not concentrated in these surface invaginations because they do not have access to the surface domain of the cell surface where these structures are located. In the case of the TM-AA/GP receptors, an increased association with clathrin-coated pits was observed whichever mode of calculation was used (Fig. 6, A and B). This suggests that the increased mobility of the TM-AA/GP receptor also increased its capacity to anchor to clathrin-coated pits. Fig. 7 shows the degradation of 125I-insulin by CHO cells expressing the four mutant receptors that exhibited decreased or accelerated insulin uptake as well as the wild-type receptor and the Ala1030 mutant. For the wild-type receptor, there was relatively little insulin degradation over the first 10 min of incubation and then an increase in rate such that 24% of the cell-associated insulin was degraded after 30 min. The TM/c-neu, +exo/cyt, and ++++exo/cyt receptors showed a reduced level of insulin degradation (ranging from 12 to 18% at 30 min), whereas the TM-AA/GP mutant had increased insulin degradation compared with the wild-type receptor (36% at 30 min). The kinase-defective Ala1030 mutant showed the lowest level of insulin degradation (11% at 30 min). Thus, the amount of degraded insulin changed in proportion to the level of insulin uptake. Preincubation of CHO cells with high concentrations of insulin (10-7M) causes a loss of cell-surface insulin receptor, i.e. down-regulation in a time-dependent manner. Fig. 8 shows a representative time course for down-regulation of 125I-insulin binding with CHO cells that overexpress wild-type insulin receptors. After 16 h of incubation, the bound/free ratio for 125I-insulin decreased by 35% as compared with that in cells incubated with buffer but without insulin for 16 h. Each mutant receptor also showed reduced surface binding of insulin after 16 h of preincubation with insulin; however, the degree of down-regulation was only 22, 18, and 15% for +exo/cyt, ++++exo/cyt, and TM/c-neu, respectively, all of which showed reduced internalization. As with other parameters, the TM-AA/GP mutant receptor showed an increased extent of down-regulation, which was ~50% greater than that of the wild-type receptor. These changes in binding were due to changes in cell-surface receptor concentration, as demonstrated by Scatchard analysis (data not shown). When assessed by insulin binding, the kinase-defective mutant receptor Ala1030 showed an unexplained, but reproducible, small increase in ligand binding following prolonged insulin pretreatment. Loss of cell-surface receptor was also estimated by changes in binding of labeled anti-receptor antibody (Fig. 9). After preincubation with 10-7M insulin for 18 h, binding of iodinated monoclonal antibody 83-14 was decreased by 30% for the wild-type receptor. The +exo/cyt, ++++exo/cyt, and TM/c-neu mutations showed reduced antibody binding by 19, 20, and 24%, respectively, whereas the TM-AA/GP mutant had a 41% decrease in antibody binding with insulin preincubation. These data confirm the fact that the loss of insulin binding is due to a loss of immunoreactive receptor protein, rather than some modification of the insulin-binding site. Furthermore, the degree of insulin-induced receptor down-regulation varied in proportion to the change in receptor internalization in each receptor mutant. In contrast to the studies with labeled insulin, however, no change in receptor was found in cells expressing the Ala1030 mutant when assessed by antibody binding. Insulin-induced receptor down-regulation is a reflection not only of receptor endocytosis, but also of synthesis, recycling, and degradation. Monensin, a calcium ionophore that inhibits receptor recycling without affecting internalization(33Carpentier J.L. Dayer J. Lang U. Silverman R. Orci L. Gorden P. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 14190-14195Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was used to further investigate the relationship between internalization and down-regulation of mutant insulin receptors. In this experiment, preincubation of CHO cells with 10-7M insulin for 3 h at 37°C caused receptor down-regulation by 27% for the wild-type receptor and between 6 and 39% for the various mutants (Table 2). When cells were incubated with insulin in the presence of 50 mM monensin for 3 h, in each case, loss of cell-surface receptors became even greater than that without monensin. For example, with monensin, the wild-type receptor was down-regulated by 36%. One can obtain an estimate of the “recycled fraction” by calculating the percent increase in down-regulation in the presence versus the absence of monensin, and for the wild-type receptor, this value was 28%. Based on similar calculations, the recycled fraction of internalized receptors was estimated to be between 23 and 36% for all cell lines. Thus, there was no significant difference in recycling of the internalized receptor to the cell surface among mutant and wild-type receptors, suggesting that the differences in receptor down-regulation can be accounted for mainly by the differences in internalization among these receptors.Tabled 1 Internalization of membrane receptors may play a critical role in their cellular function, as for example with the receptor for many nutrient-related components such as low density lipoprotein and transferrin, or may play a more regulatory role, as in the case of most hormone receptors. Evidence that the insulin receptor is involved in ligand-stimulated internalization has been present for over 15 years, but only recently have the structural determinants of this process begun to be elucidated. The present results clearly show the importance of the transmembrane domain of the insulin receptor in ligand-dependent receptor internalization as demonstrated by a decreased receptor internalization in the TM/c-neu mutant and an increased internalization in the TM-AA/GP mutant. Our data also indicate that the 3 positively charged amino acids on the cytoplasmic flank of the transmembrane domain are another determinant of receptor internalization since replacement of this sequence with uncharged amino acids (+exo/cyt and ++++exo/cyt mutations) results in impaired internalization. These findings could be confirmed measuring 125I-insulin internalization both biochemically and morphologically and by performing insulin degradation and insulin receptor down-regulation studies. These determinants of insulin-dependent receptor internalization are independent of receptor kinase activation or structure of the juxtamembrane region, both of which have been reported to be critical components in receptor internalization(10Russell D.S. Gherzi R. Johnson E. Chou C.K. Rosen O. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 11833-11840Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11McClain D.A. Maegawa H. Lee J. Dull T.J. Ullrich A. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 14663-14671Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 12Hari J. Roth R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 15341-15344Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Backer J.M. Kahn C.R. Cahill D.A. Ullrich A. White M.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 16450-16454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 14Thies R.S. Webster N.J. McClain D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10132-10137Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Gorden P. Rutter W.J. Orci L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 162-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 118: 831-839Google Scholar, 17Rajagopalan M. White M.F. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 118: 831-839Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar), since all mutants examined had normal kinase activation and an intact juxtamembrane domain. Regulation of internalization independent of kinase activation has also been suggested by Trischitta et al.(34Trischitta V. Wong K.Y. Brunetti A. Scalisi R. Vigneri R. Goldfine I.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 5041-5046Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), who showed that insulin receptor antibodies that do not activate receptor tyrosine kinase can also induce receptor internalization, and by Androlewicz et al.(35Androlewicz M.J. Brandenburg D.F. Straus D.S. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 9750-9757Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar), who reported an insulin-resistant melanoma cell line that exhibited decreased insulin-induced receptor internalization despite normal ligand-dependent kinase activation. Along with present results, these observations indicate that the mechanisms by which ligand-dependent internalization can be regulated are complex and that the structure of the TM domain and its flanking charged amino acids are major components in the regulation of this system. The uptake of insulin-receptor complexes inside target cells is preceded by surface events that can be subdivided in three steps: 1) freeing of the receptor from microvilli, where they preferentially localize in the absence of bound ligand; 2) surface redistribution from microvilli to the nonvillous domain of the cell surface; and 3) anchoring of the receptor in clathrin-coated pits(15Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Gorden P. Rutter W.J. Orci L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 162-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 118: 831-839Google Scholar). The first of these events is ligand-specific and depends on receptor kinase activation and autophosphorylation, while the third requires specific signal sequences present in the juxtamembrane domain of the receptor (15Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Gorden P. Rutter W.J. Orci L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 162-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 118: 831-839Google Scholar, 17Rajagopalan M. Neidigh J.L. McClain D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 23068-23073Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Backer J.M. Shoelson S.E. Weiss M.A. Xin Hua Q. Cheatham R.B. Haring E. Cahill D.A. White M.F. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 118: 831-839Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). Neither of these two events seems affected by the mutations used in the present study since all TM domain receptor mutants analyzed have a normally activable kinase, intact autophosphorylation sites, and preserved juxtamembrane domains. Moreover, as demonstrated by the morphological analysis, the three TM domain receptor mutants that exhibit decreased or increased internalization can leave microvilli and show a normal propensity to associate with clathrin-coated pits on the nonvillous domain of the cell surface. This is in contrast to what has been previously observed in the case of kinase-inactive or juxtamembrane mutated receptors(15Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Gorden P. Rutter W.J. Orci L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 162-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 16Carpentier J.L. Paccaud J.P. Backer J. Gilbert A. Orci L. Kahn C.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 118: 831-839Google Scholar). Thus, the altered surface redistribution of these three receptor mutants (TM-AA/GP, ++++exo/cyt, and TM/c-neu) most probably reflects altered surface mobility of these receptors. Indeed, using fluorescence photobleaching, the TM-AA/GP receptors have been shown to exhibit increased lateral mobility within the plane of the plasma membrane(30Goncalves E. Yama K. Thatte H.S. Backer J.M. Golan D.E. Kahn C.R. Shoelson S.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 5762-5766Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). This suggests that the structure of the transmembrane domain may play an important role in the interaction with the phospholipid bilayer of the plasma membrane. It is interesting to note that internalization and intracellular processing of insulin receptors are reduced in type II diabetes and obesity (36Trischitta V. Brunetti A. Chiavetta A. Benzi L. Papa V. Diabetes. 1989; 38: 1579-1584Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 37Trischitta V. Gullo D. Squatrito S. Pezzino V. Goldfine I.D. Vigneri R. J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1986; 62: 522-528Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 38Carpentier J.L. Robert A. Grunberger G. Van Obberghen E. Freychet P. Orci L. Gorden P. J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1986; 63: 151-155Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar, 39Jochen A.L. Berhanu P. Olefsky J.M. J. Clin. Endocrinol.
